item.title: Creative Hands, Joyful Hearts: Atlantic City Seniors Master Papermaking
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services wrapped up a successful Week 2 of its papermaking class, where seniors crafted unique cards, bookmarks, and gift tags using handmade paper. Special thanks to Danette Gotta and Arte Box Designs for inspiring and guiding our seniors through this creative journey.
item.content:encoded:
Week 2 of the papermaking class hosted by Atlantic City Senior Services was a vibrant continuation of creativity and learning. Participants returned with excitement as they transformed the handmade paper they crafted in the first week into beautiful and functional creations.

Under the guidance of the talented Danette Gotta from Arte Box Designs, the seniors immersed themselves in the art of making cards, bookmarks, and gift tags. Each participant brought their own flair to their projects, showcasing their growing confidence and artistic expression.

The room was filled with smiles and laughter as creativity flowed. The seniors supported one another, offering encouragement and sharing tips. The class environment fostered a strong sense of community and accomplishment.

Danette’s passion for papermaking was evident in every step of the process. Her patient teaching style and infectious enthusiasm inspired the group and elevated the overall experience.

Participants took pride in their final products, many of which they planned to gift to friends and loved ones. Seeing their work come to life brought immense satisfaction and joy.

For some seniors, this was their first time engaging in a hands-on art form. The class not only offered a creative outlet but also served as a therapeutic and enriching activity.

The success of Week 2 demonstrated the value of arts programming in senior communities. Activities like these contribute to improved mental health, social engagement, and lifelong learning.

Atlantic City Senior Services extended heartfelt gratitude to Danette Gotta and Arte Box Designs for their invaluable contribution. Their dedication to sharing their skills left a lasting impression on all participants.

As the class series continued, the enthusiasm only grew. Seniors left with new skills, cherished memories, and a renewed sense of creativity.

The papermaking class was more than an activity—it was an experience that celebrated artistry, learning, and connection among Atlantic City’s older adults.

item.title: Atlantic City Residents Earned Cash While Cleaning Their Neighborhoods Through the 2025 Clean Communities Initiative
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City’s Clean Communities Initiative returned for summer 2025, allowing residents to earn money while cleaning up their neighborhoods. The program offered a $200 monthly stipend to groups that participated in regular cleanups through October.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City’s Clean Communities Initiative officially wrapped its fourth consecutive summer of promoting neighborhood pride and environmental stewardship. Led by the Department of Public Works, the program returned in 2025 and once again provided local residents with the opportunity to earn money while actively improving their own communities.

Throughout the summer, the Public Works Department rotated through different Atlantic City wards daily, conducting neighborhood cleanups and inviting the public to join the effort. This hands-on program was designed to inspire civic responsibility and a cleaner, safer Atlantic City for all. Residents responded with enthusiasm and a shared commitment to the cause.

Groups of five or more were invited to participate by committing to clean at least four blocks twice a month. In return, these groups received a $200 monthly stipend, making the initiative a win-win: residents benefited financially while the city saw a significant reduction in litter and debris. Participants were provided with trash bags, gloves, grabbers, and safety vests to ensure an efficient and safe cleanup process.

The program also emphasized accessibility. Interested residents were able to collect applications at the Public Works Office in Room 604 at City Hall, where they also received further instructions. All inquiries during the program period were directed to Clean Communities Coordinator Angela Pittman.

The 2025 initiative officially ran through October 1, 2025, giving residents a full summer to take part. The city’s website, www.acnj.gov, hosted the initial daily cleanup schedule and other updates throughout the season, allowing participants to stay informed and engaged.

Beyond the monetary incentive, many participants cited a sense of pride and ownership in their neighborhoods as the most rewarding aspect. The program succeeded in not only cleaning the streets but also in strengthening bonds between neighbors and fostering a collective sense of responsibility.

This summer’s Clean Communities program also served as a platform for youth engagement. Several local youth groups and student organizations joined in, turning their summer break into a meaningful community service experience.

City officials expressed satisfaction with the turnout and effectiveness of the program. They noted that litter levels were visibly reduced and public response was overwhelmingly positive, setting the stage for continued growth of the initiative in future years.

The 2025 program demonstrated that with a shared goal and a small incentive, community transformation is achievable. Atlantic City residents once again showed that they are ready and willing to step up for the betterment of their neighborhoods.

item.title: Construction Commenced on Atlantic City Boardwalk Holocaust Memorial
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City began construction on the Boardwalk Holocaust Memorial, a long-awaited project honoring victims and survivors of the Holocaust. The memorial, located at Roosevelt Pavilion, will serve as a powerful site of remembrance and reflection.
item.content:encoded:
Construction officially began on the Atlantic City Boardwalk Holocaust Memorial, marking a significant step in a long-anticipated project dedicated to remembrance and reflection. On June 5, 2025, the Atlantic City Boardwalk Holocaust Memorial Committee, with the support of Mayor Marty Small, Sr. and the City of Atlantic City, held a groundbreaking ceremony at the project’s oceanfront location.

The Department of Public Works began removing boards from the designated site shortly before the ceremony, signaling the start of physical work on a vision that had been in development for years. This memorial aims to honor the victims and survivors of the Holocaust, ensuring that their stories endure and that history is never forgotten.

The site, located at the Roosevelt Pavilion on the Atlantic City Boardwalk, overlooks the Atlantic Ocean and is designed to invite quiet contemplation. The setting was selected for its visibility and serenity, providing an ideal space for individuals and families to sit on provided benches and engage in solemn remembrance.

The design of the memorial focuses on themes of remembrance and hope, incorporating architectural and symbolic elements intended to provoke thought and emotion. As visitors take in the ocean view, they will be encouraged to consider the resilience of those who suffered unimaginable atrocities and the importance of standing against hatred in all forms.

This project has been a collaborative effort, uniting city officials, local leaders, and community members under a shared commitment to education, reflection, and human rights. The support from Mayor Small and his administration has been instrumental in moving the project from concept to reality.

Community response to the beginning of construction has been one of support and solemn gratitude. Many residents see this as not just a memorial, but as a necessary and meaningful public space that speaks to the importance of acknowledging history’s darkest chapters.

As the build progresses, the memorial is expected to serve both as a historical landmark and an educational site. Its presence on the Boardwalk ensures that thousands of annual visitors will have the opportunity to engage with its message.

The Atlantic City Boardwalk Holocaust Memorial is scheduled to be completed in the fall of 2025, with an official dedication ceremony expected to follow. Once complete, the site will stand as a lasting tribute to the strength of the human spirit and the necessity of remembering the past.

The start of construction represents more than just the physical development of a space; it symbolizes a community’s promise to preserve memory, promote peace, and ensure that future generations continue to learn from history.

item.title: Atlantic City Honored Pride Month with Flag Raising Ceremony at Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City celebrated Pride Month 2025 with a flag raising ceremony at Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza, affirming its commitment to diversity and inclusion. The event brought together government leaders and the LGBTQ community in a powerful display of solidarity.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City proudly commemorated Pride Month 2025 with a vibrant and meaningful Pride Flag Raising Ceremony on Thursday, June 12, at 12:00 PM. The event took place at the newly dedicated Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza, a stunning space outside City Hall that symbolizes inclusivity, unity, and civic pride.

The ceremony was organized by the City of Atlantic City - Government, in collaboration with Atlantic City Multicultural Services and the Atlantic City LGBTQ community. Together, they created a heartfelt tribute to the diverse voices and identities that make Atlantic City a stronger, more compassionate community.

Attendees gathered under clear skies as the rainbow and transgender flags were proudly raised, signaling the city’s commitment to diversity, equality, and acceptance. The uplifting event featured remarks from city officials, community leaders, and LGBTQ advocates, each emphasizing the importance of standing in solidarity with the LGBTQ community.

Local residents and visitors alike attended the event, offering cheers and applause as the flags ascended. The moment served as both a celebration and a reminder of the ongoing work toward inclusion and justice for all.

The Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza, named after New Jersey’s late Lieutenant Governor, provided a powerful setting for the event. Its dedication to public engagement and civic pride made it an ideal space to honor the legacy of Pride and the voices pushing for equity.

Pride Month is more than a celebration—it's a call to action. By hosting this flag raising, the City of Atlantic City reaffirmed its support for LGBTQ rights and visibility, recognizing the contributions and struggles of LGBTQ individuals throughout history.

The ceremony also sparked conversations about how municipalities can lead by example in promoting inclusivity. Atlantic City's actions demonstrated that local governments play a crucial role in creating safe and affirming spaces for all.

Community members expressed appreciation for the event, noting how meaningful it was to see their city visibly support LGBTQ causes. Many attendees captured the moment with photos, proudly sharing them to spread the message of acceptance far and wide.

Through the 2025 Pride Flag Raising Ceremony, the City of Atlantic City embraced the spirit of Pride Month—one of celebration, remembrance, and forward momentum.

item.title: Senior En Blanc Delivered a Night of Elegance and Joy for Atlantic City’s Beloved Seniors

item.description: Atlantic City’s seniors enjoyed an unforgettable evening of elegance and connection at the exclusive Senior En Blanc event. Held at the All Wars Memorial Building, residents aged 55 and older celebrated community in stunning all-white attire under twinkling lights.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City’s seniors experienced a truly special night as the City hosted Senior En Blanc, an exclusive celebration held at the All Wars Memorial Building for residents aged 55 and older.

The evening combined style, grace, and warmth as attendees arrived dressed head-to-toe in white, transforming the venue into a sea of elegance and unity.

Guests were welcomed into a beautifully decorated space where twinkling lights created a magical ambiance, setting the tone for an unforgettable gathering.

Dinner was served with care, offering delicious food and refreshments that allowed neighbors to sit, share stories, and build even stronger community bonds.

Laughter echoed through the hall as old friends reconnected and new friendships were formed, all while music played and the joy of the evening carried on.

The All Wars Memorial Building provided the perfect backdrop for this radiant affair, reinforcing the city’s commitment to honoring and celebrating its senior residents.

This event was more than a dinner—it was a heartfelt gesture of appreciation for the wisdom, contributions, and presence of Atlantic City’s older generations.

The City of Atlantic City and Senior Services Department ensured the night was seamless, inclusive, and filled with thoughtful details that made each guest feel truly valued.

Photos captured the joy, smiles, and spirit of the night, offering lasting memories of a dazzling evening shared in unity and love.

Community members were encouraged to visit the Atlantic City Senior Services page for even more glimpses of this heartwarming and unforgettable experience.

item.title: Atlantic City Youth Represented as “Atlantic City Sixers” at Jr. NBA Camp
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Jr. NBA camp at MLK Complex brought energy and excitement to Atlantic City youth, who proudly became the Atlantic City Sixers as they trained in official NBA uniforms. Organized by AC Rec, the program focused on skill-building, teamwork, and community spirit.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City's young athletes recently hit the courts with passion and purpose as they took part in the Jr. NBA camp at the MLK Complex.

Decked out in official NBA uniforms, the kids were affectionately dubbed the Atlantic City Sixers, a local twist that celebrated both their enthusiasm and hometown pride.

The camp, led by the Atlantic City Recreation Department (AC Rec), focused on building core basketball skills and drills, encouraging participants to grow both on and off the court.

Through structured training sessions, youth players worked on their fundamentals—dribbling, passing, shooting, and defense—under the guidance of dedicated coaches and mentors.

More than just physical training, the Jr. NBA camp also emphasized sportsmanship, teamwork, and discipline, helping to shape confident and respectful young leaders in the community.

Parents and families showed up in support, turning each session into a lively celebration of youth development and community engagement.

AC Rec maintained an updated feed of the team standings and camp highlights, encouraging residents to follow along and cheer for their neighborhood teams.

The energy at the MLK Complex was electric, with kids embracing their roles as future stars and community ambassadors.

By participating in this nationally recognized program, Atlantic City youth experienced firsthand what it means to dream big, work hard, and represent their city with pride.

To catch up on the latest results and relive the action, residents were encouraged to follow AC Rec on social media for updates and ongoing youth programs.

item.title: Atlantic City Kicked Off a Full Year of North to Shore Festival Events for the First Time
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City made history this week as it officially launched its first full year of events for the North to Shore Festival. The kickoff was held at The Terrace at Hard Rock Hotel & Casino, signaling an exciting season ahead for locals and visitors alike.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time since its inception, the North to Shore Festival announced a full year of programming in Atlantic City, starting with a vibrant kickoff event held earlier this week.

The announcement took place at The Terrace at Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Atlantic City, where festival organizers, local officials, and community partners gathered to unveil this exciting new chapter for the city.

The North to Shore Festival—powered by Prudential—celebrates the arts, innovation, and community across New Jersey. Atlantic City is now joining Newark and Asbury Park in hosting a dynamic lineup of performances and events that showcase local culture, talent, and entertainment.

Some of the first events revealed during the kickoff include the Orange Loop Block Party on June 14, a lively street celebration promising music, food, and community fun. Also on June 14 is Bash at Back Sov, bringing high-energy skateboarding and youth-centered activities to the heart of the city.

On June 15, audiences were invited to enjoy Global Grooves, an immersive music experience celebrating diverse cultural sounds and rhythms from around the world.

Summer in Atlantic City also got a major boost with the announcement of Free Summer Concerts at Gardner’s Basin, taking place on June 21 and July 26. These outdoor shows offered residents and tourists alike a chance to unwind by the water with live music in a family-friendly atmosphere.

The expansion of the North to Shore Festival into a full-year schedule marks a milestone in Atlantic City's ongoing efforts to promote arts, culture, and community engagement year-round.

City officials expressed pride in the city's growing role as a cultural destination and encouraged residents to take part in the upcoming festivities and support local talent.

With this announcement, Atlantic City has firmly positioned itself as a year-round hub for creativity and celebration through the North to Shore Festival.

Details on these and all events happening in Atlantic City this summer and through May 2026 can be found here: https://northtoshore.com/events/

With this announcement, Atlantic City has firmly positioned itself as a year-round hub for creativity and celebration through the North to Shore Festival.

item.title: Atlantic City Unveiled Lt. Governor Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza in Tribute and Transformation
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The City of Atlantic City officially opened the Lt. Governor Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza, honoring the late Lieutenant Governor while introducing a beautifully redesigned, secure, and sustainable space outside City Hall.
item.content:encoded:
On June 5, 2025, the City of Atlantic City, in partnership with the State of New Jersey, proudly celebrated the grand opening of the Lt. Governor Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza. Located outside City Hall, this new space was named in honor of the late Lieutenant Governor, a trailblazer who left a lasting mark on New Jersey’s political and civic landscape.

Mayor Marty Small, Sr. led the ribbon-cutting ceremony alongside New Jersey Department of Community Affairs (DCA) Commissioner Jaquelyn Suarez, members of Sheila Oliver’s family, and a gathering of City, County, and State officials. The event marked both a celebration of legacy and the completion of a major public space renovation.

This project not only paid tribute to Lt. Governor Sheila Oliver but also significantly improved the public’s experience at City Hall. The main entrance, closed since construction began in spring 2024, was reopened with a covered walkway and a new security gate, enhancing both convenience and safety.

Further security upgrades included improved lighting across the courtyard, with lanterns added to the exterior walls, and reconfigured main and employee entrance doors to streamline access and safety. Sheila Oliver’s name, now prominently etched above the entrance walkway, along with her image and signage throughout the plaza, added a powerful visual tribute.

The plaza also received extensive aesthetic improvements. Visitors can now enjoy built-in benches, a thoughtfully designed rain garden, an elegant marble fountain, and a pergola that brings charm and shade to the space. Lush new trees, shrubs, and grass were planted to soften the urban setting and create a welcoming environment.

The building itself received attention as well. Existing exterior walls were power washed and repainted, restoring their original brightness and contributing to the refreshed look and feel of the City Hall complex.

To make the plaza more walkable, pedestrian space was expanded across the courtyard. These wider walking paths made the area more accessible and navigable for visitors, staff, and residents passing through the site.

In addition to the courtyard renovations, the City Hall parking lot was repaved and redesigned. A new parking attendant booth was installed at the South Carolina Avenue entrance, further improving visitor management and traffic flow.

Lastly, in line with the city’s growing commitment to renewable energy, six Electric Vehicle (EV) charging stations were scheduled to be installed later in the month—adding a forward-thinking, sustainable element to the site.

The opening of the Lt. Governor Sheila Y. Oliver Plaza marked more than the completion of a construction project—it symbolized respect for a remarkable leader and a renewed vision for civic space in Atlantic City. The plaza now stands as a lasting reminder of her legacy and the city’s dedication to accessibility, safety, and sustainability.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City High School’s 12th Annual Boat Races Made Waves with Record-Breaking Win
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The 12th Annual Boat Races at Atlantic City High School brought students together to showcase their physics knowledge through creative boat designs and exciting competition. A new school record was set by two-time champion Zuzanna Turska ’25, making this year’s race one to remember.
item.content:encoded:
The 12th Annual Boat Races at Atlantic City High School were a resounding success, drawing cheers from classmates, teachers, and visitors as students put their engineering and physics knowledge to the test on the water.

Held on campus in Atlantic City, NJ, this year’s event celebrated creativity, teamwork, and scientific application through one of the school’s most exciting traditions. Students from Honors Physics and AP Physics 1 classes participated, using principles they learned throughout the year to design and race their boats across a makeshift course.

The competition was not only about speed, but also about design, buoyancy, and innovation. Every team had the opportunity to present their vessels, explain their engineering choices, and demonstrate how physics could be applied in a practical, hands-on challenge.

The highlight of the event came when a new school record was set by Zuzanna Turska ’25, a two-time champion, and her teammates. Their boat sped across the finish line faster than any in previous years, cementing their names in the school’s physics legacy. Their victory proved to be a perfect blend of technical skill and effective collaboration.

The first-place prize went to “Puff Mobile”, created by students in the Honors Physics class. Known for its sleek design and aerodynamic efficiency, the boat outpaced its competitors while remaining remarkably stable during the race.

Second and third place were awarded to “Armstrong” and “Mayflower”, both entries from AP Physics 1. These boats demonstrated unique structural solutions and a deep understanding of force, motion, and fluid dynamics.

The event was as educational as it was entertaining, giving students the chance to engage with physics in a way that was both interactive and memorable. Teachers and spectators alike were impressed by the ingenuity on display and the energy students brought to the challenge.

The race also served as an opportunity for students to practice problem-solving, collaboration, and communication, all key components of STEM education. Whether their boats placed or not, every participant walked away with valuable experience and a sense of pride.

A big thank you went out to all who came to support the event, especially the teachers who organized it and the students who made it possible. The 12th Annual Boat Races stood as a testament to what students can achieve when given the space to explore, build, and compete.

item.title: Chelsea Heights School’s Spring Music Showcase Highlighted Young Talent and Creative Excellence
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Chelsea Heights School Spring Music Showcase celebrated the hard work and creativity of student musicians, delivering an inspiring afternoon of performances. From classic tunes to original compositions, the event highlighted the value of music education and the joy of artistic expression.
item.content:encoded:
The Chelsea Heights School Spring Music Showcase was a vibrant celebration of student musicianship, held on June 5, 2025. Families and faculty gathered to witness the culmination of months of preparation, as students took the stage to demonstrate their dedication, creativity, and passion for music.

The school's cafetorium was transformed into a performance venue filled with energy and applause. From the moment the first note played, the atmosphere was charged with excitement. Students cheered for their peers, creating a supportive and enthusiastic environment that echoed throughout the afternoon.

The event featured a wide range of musical performances, offering something for everyone. The showcase opened with the school’s violin students, who performed “Go Tell Aunt Rhody” and “Song of the Wind.” These selections, drawn from the Suzuki Violin School, Volume 1, were played with focus and charm, setting a warm tone for the rest of the program.

Adding a contemporary touch to the event, a clarinet trio delivered a well-received rendition of the pop hit “Sweater Weather.” Their performance brought a modern flair to the showcase, highlighting the students' versatility and musical adaptability.

A trumpet quartet followed with a delightful version of “London Bridge.” The familiar tune prompted audience members to hum along, creating a shared moment between performers and listeners. The nostalgic melody paired with the students’ disciplined playing made the piece both fun and impressive.

One of the most memorable moments of the afternoon was an original student composition titled “Dreamless Inspiration.” This piece, performed by a mixed-instrument quartet of violin, percussion, trombone, and clarinet, stood out for its innovative arrangement and emotional depth. The audience responded with enthusiastic applause, recognizing the creativity and collaboration behind the performance.

Instrumental Music Teacher Patrick Angelo, in his first year at Chelsea Heights School, expressed deep pride in the students’ efforts. “A lot of effort has been put in. Students have been taken out of classes for practice and rehearsals,” he shared. “They’ve worked tirelessly, and their dedication really shines through in their performances.” Angelo supported his students throughout, often joining them in rehearsal while ensuring they remained the stars of the show.

Principal James Knox praised Angelo’s leadership and impact in his first year. “He has done a marvelous, fantastic job for his first year,” Knox said. “I’m sure all of the teachers can remember that first year—I sure can.” His remarks underscored the success of the showcase as a team effort and a testament to strong arts instruction.

The Spring Music Showcase served as more than just a school concert—it was a shining example of how music education can empower students with confidence, discipline, and self-expression. As the final note faded and the applause settled, it was clear that the event had left a lasting impression on both the performers and the audience.

item.title: PAS Students Captivated Audiences in Dazzling "101 Dalmatians Kids" Production
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Students at Pennsylvania Avenue School impressed audiences with their lively and heartfelt performance of "101 Dalmatians Kids", the final show of the school year. The production celebrated creativity, courage, and the transformative power of the performing arts.
item.content:encoded:
The Pennsylvania Avenue School’s Visual Performing Arts students took center stage in a delightful presentation of "101 Dalmatians Kids", earning praise for their talent, dedication, and teamwork. Performed in early June 2025, the show was a highlight of the school year and a celebration of the power of the arts in education.

The production showcased the strength of the school’s thriving arts program, led by passionate educators and committed young performers. Dr. Nycole Lyles-Belton, a key organizer, shared how proud the staff was of the students' work ethic and growth throughout the process. “They worked hard, and we’re proud of them,” she said. “It was great to see the students take responsibility, take their books home, learn their parts and learn the songs.”

Preparation for the performance spanned weeks, with students rehearsing after school and on Saturdays. Their dedication, guided by their teachers, helped them master both lines and songs. The students put their hearts into the project, overcoming stage fright and stepping into their roles with courage and enthusiasm.

“They put their hearts into it,” Lyles-Belton noted. “To be able to perform on a stage in front of people is nerve-wracking—it’s nerve-wracking for adults. So, to see the students get up and do this with courage, I’m very pleased.” The rehearsal process also fostered teamwork, a sense of community, and deepened each student’s confidence.

The students performed the play three times. The first show welcomed parents, offering a more intimate environment where families could watch their children shine. Family members like Mecca Faulkner, Medinah Law, Billie Shannon, and Yah’Cirah Morgan came out to support Jonirah and Johnny Morgan, who played leading roles. The audience was thrilled by the students’ ability to deliver lines and capture the spirit of the story. “It was wonderful,” said Faulkner. “It was energetic and well put together,” added Law.

The next two performances were opened to the school community, allowing teachers, students, and staff to experience the production. These showings helped transform the school into a hub of culture and creative energy, showcasing the impact of the arts on school spirit and student expression.

The production of "101 Dalmatians Kids", based on the classic Disney tale, came to life through the students’ playful energy and commitment. Their interpretation of the brave Dalmatian puppies who outsmart Cruella de Vil delighted audiences of all ages. From expressive acting to enthusiastic singing, each student made the story their own.

Visual details also stood out. The costumes, set design, and props were crafted with care and creativity. From spotted T-shirts and puppy ears to Cruella’s signature coat and necklace, every element helped bring the story to life. The show balanced humor and heart, immersing attendees in a whimsical theatrical experience.

Among the standout moments were the musical numbers, including the catchy “Kanine Crunchies” commercial song. Sa’Ni Williams, a fifth grader who played Cruella de Vil, gave a memorable performance with strong stage presence and vocal delivery. “I just tried to project my voice,” said Williams. “It was pretty fun.”

As the curtain closed on the school year’s final production, the Visual Performing Arts program looked ahead with excitement. The success of "101 Dalmatians Kids" reaffirmed the school’s commitment to nurturing student talent through performance opportunities. “It all came together like a well-oiled machine,” said Lyles-Belton. The students' achievement served as a shining example of what is possible when dedication, creativity, and support converge.

item.title: A Day of Joy and Celebration: MLK Fun Day 2025 Brought Smiles and School Spirit
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex in Atlantic City hosted a vibrant and joy-filled MLK Fun Day 2025, turning an ordinary school day into an extraordinary celebration of community, effort, and fun. Thanks to student-led fundraising, the event was completely free and left everyone smiling.
item.content:encoded:
The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex in Atlantic City recently hosted a lively and unforgettable event — MLK Fun Day 2025 — that brought students, staff, and the community together for a full day of celebration, fun, and connection.

Serving both as a reward for students who excelled throughout the year and encouragement for those needing a boost, the day reflected the school’s commitment to both achievement and inclusivity. Principal Jodi Burroughs shared that the main goal was to allow kids to enjoy themselves in a safe and supportive environment.

“The beauty of this is that kids get to be kids and have fun in a safe space,” said Burroughs.

Seventh and eighth graders enjoyed a unique treat: access to the newly renovated Pop Lloyd Stadium, where a spirited kickball tournament brought out the best in student teamwork and athletic energy. The stadium buzzed with cheers and laughter as students ran bases, competed with pride, and supported their peers.

Back on school grounds, the school yard was transformed into a vibrant carnival-style playground, complete with inflatable bouncy houses, slides, popcorn, and snow cones. A variety of sports stations gave students the chance to test their skills, while music from a DJ added rhythm and energy to every corner of the event.

Inside the auditorium, creativity and fun took center stage. Students participated in interactive games like Paper Dragon, which challenged them to unroll ribbons using arm circles within 60 seconds, and Dizzy Mummy, where teams of two wrapped each other in toilet paper without breaking it. These games highlighted the students' creativity, agility, and sense of humor.

A standout element of this event was its cost-free experience for all participants. Thanks to student-led fundraising efforts, including book fairs and popcorn sales held throughout the school year, Fun Day was entirely funded without placing any burden on students or families.

“They pay for nothing, and it’s all because of their fundraising,” said Burroughs. “They did small book fairs, popcorn sales and other things. Fun Day is great because it encourages them to do well.”

With high energy, laughter, and unity, MLK Fun Day 2025 left lasting memories for students and staff alike. It stood as a testament to the school’s dedication to recognizing effort, fostering community, and making space for students to simply be kids.


Photo Credit to: Mark Tyler, District Communications Specialist

item.title: Atlantic City Celebrated Young Athletes at the Elementary Track Meet Championship
item.dc:creator: Christina Noble and Tasha Devonish
item.description: Atlantic City’s young athletes gave it their all at the Elementary Track Meet Championship, a day filled with energy, teamwork, and unforgettable moments. The city came together to celebrate the strength and spirit of its rising stars.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Elementary Track Meet Championship was successfully held, bringing together young athletes from across the city to compete and showcase their skills on the track. The event highlighted the dedication, sportsmanship, and determination of each participant.

Students from various elementary schools gave their best performance in different track events. From sprinting to relay races, every moment was filled with energy and excitement. These young competitors displayed remarkable teamwork and a strong sense of community spirit.

Support poured in from families, coaches, and teachers, who stood by the sidelines cheering passionately. Their encouragement played a vital role in motivating the students to give their all and enjoy the experience.

The event served as a reminder of how powerful youth programs can be in building not only physical strength but also confidence, discipline, and a sense of belonging. The track meet provided a platform for children to push their limits and feel the pride of participation and achievement.

Organized by Atlantic City Youth Services, the meet emphasized the importance of sports and extracurricular activities in youth development. Their continued support for such initiatives contributes greatly to nurturing future champions.

Each race brought thrilling moments, and every child who participated walked away with a sense of accomplishment. The spirit of healthy competition and mutual respect was evident throughout the day.

The enthusiastic atmosphere, coupled with perfect weather and a well-organized event, made it a memorable occasion for everyone involved. Volunteers and staff worked behind the scenes to ensure the day ran smoothly.

Special recognition was given to the schools and coaches who prepared the students with dedication. Their efforts were clearly reflected in the students’ performances and positive attitudes.

This event stood as a celebration of Atlantic City’s investment in its youth and the bright future that lies ahead. The elementary track meet was not just a competition—it was a showcase of potential, perseverance, and community pride.

As the day came to a close, smiles and applause filled the air. The young athletes left with not only medals and ribbons but with memories that will inspire them for years to come.

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Racked Up Good Times at Pool Day
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services hosted an unforgettable day of fun, games, and connection around the pool table. It wasn’t just about billiards — it was about bringing seniors together in celebration and joy.
item.content:encoded:
It was more than just a game, it was a celebration of connection, laughter, and pure fun as Atlantic City Senior Services hosted a spirited pool day for our local seniors.

The event welcomed residents from across the city to gather, play, and enjoy each other's company around the billiard table. The sounds of cue balls cracking, friendly chatter, and light-hearted competition filled the room throughout the day.

While Merriam-Webster might define pool as “a game played with a cue stick to strike balls on a table,” Atlantic City Senior Services proudly redefined it as a day of fun, camaraderie, and joyful engagement for our seniors.

Participants arrived wearing bright smiles and even brighter new shirts, adding color and excitement to the day. The new shirts were a hit, helping everyone feel part of something special.

Several rounds of games were played, with participants cheering each other on whether they sank every ball or missed their shot. The focus was less on winning and more on enjoying the moment and each other’s company.

The event proved once again that staying active and socially connected is not only good for physical health but also vital for emotional well-being, especially in our senior years.

Beyond the billiards, the room buzzed with stories, laughter, and a sense of shared history among peers. For some, it was a trip down memory lane; for others, a brand-new hobby discovered later in life.

Atlantic City Senior Services staff ensured that everyone felt welcome and supported, creating a safe and inclusive space for all abilities and skill levels.

As the day wrapped up, many were already asking when the next game day would be. The success of this event reminded us how something as simple as a pool table can create meaningful moments.

item.title: Atlantic City Makes the List: Top Affordable Beach Town Where You Can Live, Work, and Thrive
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Discover why Atlantic City was just ranked the #3 Most Affordable Beach Town in America by Realtor.com. With strategic investments, cultural revival, and career-building opportunities, Atlantic City isn’t just a beach town. It’s a place to live, work, and thrive.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City has once again captured national attention, this time earning the #3 spot on Realtor.com’s 2025 list of “Most Affordable Beach Towns for Homebuyers.” With its combination of coastal charm, accessible home prices, and a city government deeply invested in revitalization, it’s no surprise Atlantic City is being recognized as one of the best places in the country to live, work, and thrive.

At the 17th Annual Jersey Shorecast, hosted by Stockton University’s Lloyd D. Levenson Institute of Gaming, Hospitality and Tourism (LIGHT), regional experts discussed what lies ahead for the 2025 summer season. Despite cautious outlooks around consumer spending, labor shortages, and international travel, Atlantic City continues to attract attention for one critical reason: opportunity.

And now, there's new national recognition to back it up.

‍

‍

Realtor.com evaluated dozens of coastal destinations nationwide, considering median home prices, inventory levels, and location appeal. Atlantic City rose to the top thanks to its affordable housing stock including single-family homes and condos and its strategic position as both a beach resort and growing year-round city. The report, which evaluated coastal cities based on median home prices and inventory levels, reinforces what residents, investors, and city leaders have long known: you don’t have to be a millionaire to live near the ocean or build a future by it.

This national spotlight underscores what locals already know. Atlantic City offers more than just affordability. It's a city in motion, with new events, festivals, and immersive experiences and emerging as a bright spot on the East Coast, where affordability, investment potential, and cultural revitalization intersect. Whether you're a full-time resident or weekend traveler, there's always something happening in Atlantic City.

‍

#LiveinAC: Affordable Beach Living, Rich in Culture

‍

Atlantic City’s local leadership is actively investing in growth, quality of life, and opportunity. Recent public investments include beach replenishment, roadway improvements, and beautification efforts, all of which are making the city more walkable, livable, and visually appealing. These efforts are part of a larger strategy to enhance quality of life and attract both new residents and investors alike.

With a median home price well below the national average for beach towns, Atlantic City offers families, professionals, and retirees an accessible path to coastal living. But it’s not just about the ocean views. It’s about quality of life. From beach replenishment projects and newly paved roads to art installations and free family-friendly events, Atlantic City is actively investing in becoming a place where residents can thrive.

The city’s new "Keep it Local" campaign encourages residents and visitors to support small businesses that reflect the city's diverse culture and entrepreneurial energy. That same local spirit extends to new programs like the Small Business Academy, which equips residents with the tools to launch or grow their own businesses.

‍

‍

#WorkinAC: Adapting and Innovating in Tourism and Beyond

‍

Whether you #WorkInAC or just visiting, there's always something to do in Atlantic City. A growing lineup of cultural events, concerts, and festivals, including the newly expanded Soar & Shore Festival, is helping extend the city’s tourism season and turn quick visits into longer stays. With amenities like golf courses, wineries, and free beachfront attractions within reach, Atlantic City is emerging as a year-round destination where lifestyle and opportunity intersect.

But the work doesn’t stop there. The city is actively creating new pathways in industries beyond tourism. Through programs like Atlantic City's Youth summer employment, partnerships with Atlantic Cape Community College and Stockton University, and the expansion of tech and digital media internships through initiatives like the Great Day Atlantic City platform, local residents are gaining access to training and career opportunities in areas such as communications, IT, digital marketing, and public service.

Local Entrepreneurs, too, are finding support through business development workshops, city grant programs, and networking resources that are growing Atlantic City’s small business ecosystem. Whether it's starting a café, launching a clothing brand, or managing a new hospitality concept, residents are finding new ways to build careers and create community wealth.

‍

#InvestinAC: A City Poised for Long-Term Growth

‍

This ranking reinforces what many already believe: Atlantic City is not just a place to vacation, it’s a place to build a life. With revitalized neighborhoods, small business support programs, and regional marketing campaigns highlighting the city's strengths, Atlantic City continues to attract first-time homebuyers, entrepreneurs, and families seeking a new beginning by the sea.

In addition to attracting national recognition for housing affordability, Atlantic City is capturing investor interest thanks to city-led infrastructure upgrades and public-private collaboration.

Beautification efforts---from the City's four community development corporations' street banners to boardwalk improvements, are revitalizing the city’s look and feel. Meanwhile, behind the scenes, Atlantic City’s IT Department recently saved taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars by handling complex installations in-house, demonstrating the kind of fiscal responsibility and innovation that creates trust for future investment.

The big takeaway from this year’s Jersey Shorecast? While some coastal towns may be bracing for slower growth, Atlantic City is building momentum. Through resilience, reinvention, and community-driven strategies, the city is positioning itself as more than a beach town—it’s becoming a place where you can build a life, a business, and a future.

‍

#LiveinAC  |  #WorkinAC  |  #InvestinAC

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Walked the Boardwalk Once Again with Strength and Spirit
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services brought the community back to the boardwalk for another invigorating 5-mile walk from Tennessee Avenue to the Ocean Club and back. The event celebrated health, connection, and the beauty of our city.

Atlantic City Senior Services made a strong return to the boardwalk, leading a group of enthusiastic seniors on a revitalizing walk that spanned five miles. This time, the route stretched from Tennessee Avenue all the way to the Ocean Club, and then back—highlighting both stamina and community spirit.

Participants embraced the opportunity to stay active while enjoying the serene ocean views and fresh coastal air. The boardwalk, known as one of Atlantic City's greatest assets, provided the perfect backdrop for this wellness-focused activity.

The walk was more than just a form of exercise—it was a celebration of the lifestyle Atlantic City offers. As one participant shared, “When you live in the most beautiful place, why wouldn't you spend as much time as possible walking the boardwalk?” That sentiment echoed among the group as they paced together in unity.

The atmosphere was filled with positive energy, laughter, and encouragement. It was a chance to reconnect with peers, reflect on personal health goals, and feel proud of accomplishing a 5-mile round-trip walk.

This initiative underscored the commitment of Atlantic City Senior Services to promote active aging, social engagement, and community pride. Every step taken on the boardwalk was a step toward better health and a stronger community bond.

Volunteers and staff walked alongside participants, providing support and ensuring everyone felt safe and encouraged. Their presence made a real difference and helped bring the community even closer together.

By reintroducing these regular walks, Atlantic City Senior Services demonstrated that age is no barrier to achieving great things. Events like these inspire others in the community to take advantage of local resources and stay connected through shared activities.

With its scenic views, ocean breeze, and welcoming spirit, the Atlantic City boardwalk proved once again to be more than just a tourist attraction—it’s a wellness destination for residents, especially seniors.

Moving forward, seniors can expect more opportunities to engage, move, and thrive as part of a city that values wellness and active living.

Atlantic City is not just a place to live—it’s a place to live well.

item.title: Atlantic City Encouraged Voter Participation During Early Voting for 2025 Primary
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributor
item.description: Atlantic City successfully concluded its early voting period for the 2025 Primary Election, held from June 3rd to June 8th, allowing residents to cast their ballots ahead of time. The city emphasized accessibility and voter convenience throughout the process.
item.content:encoded:
The early voting period for the 2025 Primary Election in Atlantic County officially takes place from Tuesday, June 3rd through Sunday, June 8th, offering residents the opportunity to cast their votes ahead of Election Day.

Atlantic City government reminded residents that they did not have to vote in the town where they reside, making the early voting process more accessible and convenient for many. This flexibility allowed voters to choose from several polling locations across the county.

Voters took advantage of the early voting window to avoid potential long lines and last-minute issues on Primary Day. The initiative aimed to increase voter turnout and ensure that every voice could be heard well before the official election date.

Throughout the week, the designated early voting locations were open to all registered voters in Atlantic County, regardless of their municipality. This encouraged participation across communities and helped make the election process smoother and more efficient.

City officials and volunteers worked hard to make sure all voting locations were properly staffed and equipped to handle the volume of early voters. Voters appreciated the convenience and the organized process.

The City of Atlantic City continued its efforts to promote civic engagement by sharing information about the early voting dates and procedures through official channels and community outreach.

Clear signage and voter assistance were made available at polling locations, ensuring a seamless experience for first-time and returning voters alike. Accessibility was also a priority, with ADA-compliant facilities at all early voting sites.

This year’s early voting effort reflected the City’s commitment to maintaining a fair and transparent electoral process. Many residents expressed appreciation for the opportunity to vote at a time that best fit their schedules.

By promoting early voting, the City hoped to reduce Election Day congestion and make civic participation more inclusive and manageable.

The success of the early voting period set a strong foundation for future elections, reinforcing the importance of community involvement and voter preparedness.

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Explore Nature During 2nd Annual Black Birders Event at Forsythe Refuge
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services hosted its 2nd Annual Black Birders Event at the Edwin B. Forsythe Wildlife Refuge, offering seniors a day of learning, exploration, and connection with nature. The event featured a scenic wetland drive, a guided forest hike, and a shared lunch.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Senior Services recently held its 2nd Annual Black Birders Event at the Edwin B. Forsythe Wildlife Refuge, offering local seniors an unforgettable day immersed in the beauty and education of the natural world.

The event was designed to highlight the importance of inclusivity in outdoor spaces while celebrating Black Birders Week, a national movement that promotes diversity in birding and environmental awareness.

Seniors participated in a range of outdoor activities beginning with a scenic drive tour through the Wetlands, where they observed local wildlife and learned about the ecology of the refuge. The ride provided a relaxing and informative introduction to the day’s exploration.

Following the drive, participants enjoyed a delicious lunch that gave everyone a chance to socialize and reflect on their surroundings. The sense of community and appreciation for nature was present throughout the event.

After lunch, seniors embarked on a guided hike through the forest trails of the reserve. With the help of expert guides, they explored native plants, birds, and ecosystems that are unique to the Forsythe area.

The hike not only allowed for physical activity but also sparked conversations about environmental stewardship and the importance of preserving local habitats for future generations.

The Friends of Forsythe NWR played a critical role in making this day possible, offering support, guidance, and resources that made the event both educational and enjoyable.

‍

Atlantic City Senior Services emphasized how fortunate the city is to have such rich natural resources nearby. They expressed gratitude for the opportunity to expose seniors to these experiences and encourage lifelong learning.

The event reinforced the idea that it's never too late to learn something new, enjoy nature, and be part of a meaningful cause. It also highlighted the ongoing commitment of the city to support inclusive programming for all its residents.

This annual tradition continues to grow in impact and popularity, and Atlantic City Senior Services looks forward to expanding the event even further in the years to come.

‍

Photo Credit: Atlantic City Senior Services

item.title: Atlantic City Graduates 27 Aspiring Entrepreneurs through Small Business Academy
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The City of Atlantic City proudly celebrated the graduation of 27 residents from its Small Business Academy, an eight-week intensive program designed to guide aspiring entrepreneurs. The latest cohort concluded with a pitch competition, awarding a $15,000 grant to local caterer Tabriah Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
Twenty-seven Atlantic City residents celebrated a major milestone this week, completing the City’s Small Business Academy, a free, eight-week training program that prepares residents to start and grow successful businesses.

The program, a partnership between the City of Atlantic City and the African American Chamber of Commerce of New Jersey (AACCNJ), featured expert-led workshops covering essential business topics such as licensing and registration, business planning, goal setting, marketing, and more. The course concluded with a pitch competition where participants presented their business ideas to local professionals for feedback and scoring.

‍

Tabriah Taylor was named the top presenter for her plan to expand her catering business and received a $15,000 grant from the Inlet Community Development Corporation (CDC). Lonniyell Sykes and Paidra Lucas were awarded second and third place, respectively.

Established in 2021 under the leadership of Mayor Marty Small Sr., the Small Business Academy is part of a larger effort to promote inclusive economic development and equip residents with practical tools for long-term success. The Mayor has prioritized investing in residents as a way to grow the local economy from within, focusing on initiatives that build self-sufficiency, innovation, and opportunity.

The City’s Economic Development Department, led by Bruce Weekes and Pam Fields, coordinated this latest cohort alongside Carmen Gates, AACCNJ Vice President of Community Development and External Affairs. Their efforts reflect the City’s ongoing work to cultivate entrepreneurship at the neighborhood level.

This graduation comes as part of a broader strategy to support small businesses across Atlantic City. Earlier this month, the City launched the Keep it Local campaign and declared May Small Business Month, encouraging residents and visitors to support locally owned businesses and showcasing the vital role these businesses play in the city’s growth and culture.

Together, these efforts signal a clear focus: Atlantic City is committed to being a place where people can thrive, work, and invest. The Small Business Academy is not only helping individuals pursue their dreams, it’s helping to build a stronger, more resilient Atlantic City.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City Commemorated Memorial Day with a Special Ceremony at All Wars Memorial Building
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City marked Memorial Day with a heartfelt observance at the All Wars Memorial Building, commemorating its 100-year anniversary and honoring the fallen with dignity and gratitude. The community gathered in solemn remembrance of those who served and sacrificed.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City held its annual Memorial Day Observance with a moving tribute to the courageous men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in service to the United States. The community came together in solemn remembrance, honoring the legacy of those who laid down their lives to protect the nation's freedoms.

This year's observance took on an even more poignant tone as it coincided with the 100-year anniversary of the All Wars Memorial Building. The event was held at this historic site, which has long stood as a testament to the valor and dedication of American service members across generations.

Local officials, veterans, community leaders, and residents gathered for the ceremony, reflecting on the significance of Memorial Day and the continued importance of preserving its meaning. The Memorial Day Observance featured heartfelt speeches, the laying of wreaths, and a moment of silence in memory of the fallen.

Veterans and family members of those who served shared personal stories, adding a powerful emotional depth to the occasion. Their accounts reminded attendees of the real human cost of war and the enduring bravery of those who answered the call of duty.

The All Wars Memorial Building served not only as the backdrop but as a symbol of resilience and remembrance. Its centennial celebration marked a century of honoring service and sacrifice within the Atlantic City community.

Musical tributes, including performances of the national anthem and other patriotic songs, further enhanced the reflective atmosphere. Attendees stood united in respect, many wearing symbolic red, white, and blue to show solidarity.

Children and students were also present, some participating in the event, demonstrating the importance of educating the next generation about the value of remembrance and national service.

Mayor Marty Small Sr., along with other city officials, emphasized the city’s commitment to honoring its veterans and the ongoing efforts to maintain Atlantic City as a place of historical significance and civic pride.

The Memorial Day Observance served as a powerful reminder that freedom comes at a cost—and that cost is borne by brave individuals and their families. Atlantic City’s tribute was both heartfelt and dignified, capturing the spirit of unity and respect.

As the event concluded, attendees were invited to reflect at the memorial, leaving flowers and flags in tribute. The ceremony was a fitting homage to those who gave all, and a reaffirmation of the community’s enduring gratitude.

‍

item.title: Starting a Business? Here’s Why You Should Do It in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: With new resources, citywide support, and a culture of entrepreneurship, Atlantic City is primed for small business success.
item.content:encoded:
For over 25 years, Joe Molineaux has been at the intersection of community and commerce—guiding municipalities and individuals through the challenges and opportunities of launching and growing businesses. Now, as a business development consultant for the City of Atlantic City, Molineaux says he’s never seen conditions more favorable for entrepreneurs than what exists in the city today.

“There’s never been a better time, based on the resources available, the commitment of city leadership, the real estate options, and the current business needs—for someone to start a business in Atlantic City,” said Molineaux.

That optimism isn’t just rhetoric—it’s backed by a groundswell of programs and infrastructure designed to support local entrepreneurs at every stage of their journey.

A City Committed to Nurturing New Business

Molineaux recently partnered with the City’s Department of Planning & Development to lead a free “Navigating the Process” seminar at City Hall. The goal? To demystify the first steps of starting a business and connect aspiring entrepreneurs with the tools and people they need to succeed.

The seminar offered real-world insights into:

  • Why now is the perfect time to launch a business in Atlantic City
  • Common pitfalls and misconceptions about entrepreneurship
  • Steps for registering and licensing a new business
  • How to create a business plan that works
  • Funding sources and local supports available

According to Molineaux, what makes Atlantic City unique isn’t just the affordability of commercial real estate or the increasing foot traffic from new development—it’s the ecosystem of support.

“From the City’s direct investment in entrepreneurship to the Community Development Corporations (CDCs) located in every ward, Atlantic City is leading the way in creating a nurturing environment for business owners,” he said. “There’s a genuine effort here to move residents forward—not just through business ownership, but through education, mentorship, and support for day-to-day living.”

A City on the Move

Molineaux's message echoes a broader truth felt across Atlantic City: this is a city on the rise, and entrepreneurship is one of its most powerful tools for equitable growth.

Through initiatives like the Small Business Academy, the “How to Do Business with Atlantic City” seminars, and the newly launched Keep It Local campaign, Mayor Marty Small Sr. and the Planning & Development team are making it clear: Atlantic City is not only open for business—it’s investing in it.

This spring, the City also declared May as “Small Business Month”, highlighting the critical role small businesses play in local identity, economic development, and generational opportunity.

Advice for Future Founders

For those considering a business of their own, Molineaux offers this advice:
“Do something every day that moves your dream forward. Research, ask questions, find mentors. Don’t go it alone—and don’t wait for perfect timing. The time is now.”

Additional “Navigating the Process” workshops are already being planned in Atlantic City for the months ahead. Residents interested in launching a business are encouraged to connect with their local CDCs or the City’s Department of Planning & Development for updates and support.

‍

item.title: Mayor Small and Atlantic City Honored Fallen Heroes at Memorial Day Ceremony
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Mayor Marty Small Sr. and the City of Atlantic City honored our fallen heroes during a solemn and heartfelt Memorial Day Ceremony at the Saracini-O'Neill 9/11 Memorial. The event served as a powerful tribute to those who made the ultimate sacrifice in service to the nation.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City, led by Mayor Marty Small Sr., commemorated Memorial Day with a touching ceremony held at the Saracini-O'Neill 9/11 Memorial. The gathering was a moving tribute to the brave men and women who have given their lives in defense of the country.

Set against the backdrop of the city’s 9/11 memorial, the ceremony brought together city officials, veterans, families, and community members to reflect on the meaning of sacrifice, service, and remembrance.

Mayor Small and other city leaders delivered remarks that emphasized the importance of remembering those who served and honoring their legacy not just on Memorial Day, but every day.

The event marked the beginning of the Memorial Day weekend, reminding residents and visitors alike of the true significance behind the holiday.

The Saracini-O'Neill 9/11 Memorial, named in honor of local heroes, provided a poignant and powerful setting for the ceremony. Attendees were encouraged to pause, reflect, and pay their respects to those who gave their lives for freedom.

The City also announced an additional Memorial Day Observance, which was scheduled for the following day at the All Wars Memorial Building located at 1510 Adriatic Avenue. This observance aimed to further honor the memory of all fallen service members across generations and conflicts.

These ceremonies are part of Atlantic City’s ongoing commitment to recognize and uplift the stories of veterans and fallen soldiers, ensuring their bravery and service are never forgotten.

Residents and visitors who attended the event shared a sense of unity, patriotism, and deep appreciation for those who have defended our nation.

The City of Atlantic City extended its gratitude to all who participated in the ceremonies and encouraged continued support for military families and veteran communities throughout the year.

item.title: Atlantic City Residents Experienced Art, Culture, and Peace at BAPS Shri Swaminarayan
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services team and local residents visited the BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in Robbinsville for a peaceful and enriching cultural experience. The trip offered an opportunity to reflect on art, architecture, and cultural understanding.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services recently visited the BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir – Akshardham in Robbinsville, New Jersey. Known as the Cultural Jewel of India, the mandir offered residents a unique and unforgettable journey into traditional Indian art, architecture, and spirituality.

The visit highlighted the stunning craftsmanship of the mandir, which features intricate hand-carved stonework and traditional design elements. Participants were guided through the site, where they learned about the construction process and the cultural and spiritual significance behind every detail.

The group had the opportunity to reflect in the mandir’s serene and peaceful environment, making the visit not only educational but also deeply calming and introspective.

Beyond its architectural beauty, the mandir serves as a vibrant community hub, offering programs and initiatives that promote service, unity, and cultural understanding. These values align closely with the mission of Atlantic City’s Multicultural Services to foster inclusion and respect across diverse communities.

The outing provided a meaningful opportunity for residents to connect with traditions outside their own and to deepen their appreciation for the richness of global cultures.

It also reinforced the importance of cultural exploration as a path toward greater empathy, awareness, and peaceful coexistence in our increasingly interconnected world.

Participants shared their reflections and expressed gratitude for the chance to experience such a powerful example of living tradition and artistry.

The trip served as a reminder of the beauty and value found in engaging with different cultures, and how such experiences can broaden perspectives and strengthen community bonds.

The City of Atlantic City thanked everyone who joined the outing and looks forward to organizing more cultural visits that inspire learning, connection, and mutual respect.

item.title: Atlantic City's 2025 Summer Season Begins with Traditional Sea Unlocking Ceremony

Joining Mayor Small at the event were several key city officials and community leaders. These included Atlantic City Police Department Chief James Sarkos, Atlantic City Fire Department Chief and Office of Emergency Management Coordinator Scott Evans, Atlantic City Beach Patrol Chief Steve Downey, Public Safety Director Sean Riggin, and Resorts Casino Hotel President and CEO Mark Giannantonio.

Their presence underscored the city’s focus on public safety, emergency preparedness, and community engagement as critical components of the summer season.

The “Opening of the Sea” ceremony has long been a cherished tradition in Atlantic City, celebrating the city’s connection to the ocean and its role as a top summer destination on the East Coast.

‍

With the season officially underway, city departments and community partners prepared to welcome thousands of visitors to Atlantic City’s beaches, boardwalk, and attractions.

The kickoff event not only highlighted the city's readiness for summer but also showcased its unity and shared vision for continued growth and success.

As the 2025 summer season began, the energy and excitement of the opening ceremony served as a powerful reminder of Atlantic City's resilience, hospitality, and commitment to being a world-class destination.

item.title: Atlantic City Honors Local Businesses and IT Department for Innovation, Impact, and Community Excellence
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Celebrating the people and organizations helping Atlantic City grow stronger, smarter, and more connected.
item.content:encoded:
At a recent City Council meeting, the City of Atlantic City recognized a group of exceptional local businesses and dedicated city staff whose efforts are helping shape a more vibrant, efficient, and forward-thinking Atlantic City. From restaurant owners to IT technicians, these honorees represent the best of what it means to live, work, and invest in the city.

Celebrating Small Business Month: Local Legends and Community Cornerstones

In honor of Small Business Month, the City’s Economic Development team—part of the Planning & Development Department—formed an internal committee to highlight small businesses that have made an undeniable impact on the local economy and community life.

The inaugural group of honorees included a diverse and dynamic lineup of beloved establishments:

  • Dock’s Oyster House – Business Excellence Award
  • Gilchrist Restaurant – Resiliency Award
  • Barbera Seafood Market – Community Spirit Award
  • The Irish Pub Atlantic City – Community Spirit Award
  • Kelsey’s Atlantic City – Growth & Economic Development Award
  • Tony Boloney’s / Mad Mutz – Innovation Award
  • Swapz AC – Emerging Pioneer Award
  • Vagabond Kitchen & Tap House – Community Impact Award
  • Miss Audrey’s Thrift Shop – Legacy Award

Recognizing neighborhood-specific contributions, local Community Development Corporations (CDCs) also nominated outstanding small businesses in their respective wards:

  • North Beach Mini Golf (Inlet CDC)
  • Center City Deli (Midtown CDC)
  • Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria (Ducktown CDC)

These businesses are more than storefronts—they are economic drivers, cultural landmarks, and places where the community gathers, celebrates, and supports one another. Their recognition reflects the city’s larger mission to make Atlantic City a place where entrepreneurship thrives and local pride runs deep.

Spotlight on Innovation: IT Department Delivers Big Wins Behind the Scenes

While local business owners power Atlantic City’s street-level economy, the City Council also took time to celebrate the often-unseen efforts of its own team, specifically, the Information Technology (IT) Department.

Led by Director Patrick Quinlan and supported by team members Tony Dabney and Kyshawn Wyman, the department was honored for recent accomplishments that have had a direct financial and operational impact on the city.

Among their standout achievements:

  • Saving more than $250,000 at Pop Lloyd Stadium and over $100,000 at the Atlantic City Aquarium by installing advanced surveillance systems in-house rather than outsourcing the work.
  • Playing a critical role in preventing a major cybersecurity attack, demonstrating not only technical expertise but also a proactive commitment to safeguarding city operations and resident data.

These efforts embody the kind of innovation, accountability, and behind-the-scenes excellence that keeps Atlantic City running efficiently and safely. It’s also a reminder that every dollar saved is a dollar that can be reinvested into community services, infrastructure, and future opportunities.

‍

‍

‍

A Culture of Recognition, a City on the Rise

Together, the honored businesses and IT professionals represent the diverse strengths within Atlantic City—vision, resilience, creativity, and dedication. Whether it’s through customer service or server security, each honoree is playing a role in the city’s ongoing transformation.

By taking the time to publicly acknowledge their contributions, the City of Atlantic City reinforces a culture of appreciation, excellence, and shared progress.

item.title: A New Era of Leadership in the Atlantic City Fire Department

item.title: Honoring Those Who Served: Atlantic City Supports Veterans at South Jersey Regional Stand Down

item.description: The City of Atlantic City joined community leaders, volunteers, and organizations at the South Jersey Regional Stand Down, offering care and critical services to homeless and at-risk veterans. The event, held at the All Wars Memorial Building, served as a powerful reminder of our duty to those who served.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City recently stood in strong support of its veteran community during the annual South Jersey Regional Stand Down at the historic All Wars Memorial Building. This impactful event brought together local leaders, volunteers, and agencies in a united effort to serve those who once served us.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. and city officials were present to engage with veterans and reinforce the city’s ongoing commitment to their well-being. The event provided a wide range of services to homeless and at-risk veterans, many of whom face daily struggles navigating access to care, benefits, and basic resources.

Throughout the day, veterans received hot meals, clothing, and access to medical care, mental health services, and benefits assistance. For many, it was more than just support—it was a reminder that their service had not been forgotten.

The atmosphere was one of dignity and mutual respect. Volunteers moved with purpose, service providers worked with compassion, and every interaction was a small act of honoring the immense sacrifices veterans have made for the country.

The All Wars Memorial Building, with its rich history and deep symbolism, provided a fitting venue. It stood not just as a backdrop, but as a testament to the bravery and resilience of the men and women being served within its walls.

Mayor Small emphasized that caring for veterans is more than just a good deed—it’s a responsibility. "Taking care of our veterans isn’t just important—it’s our duty," he shared during the event, reinforcing the message that gratitude must be backed by meaningful action.

City staff and partnering agencies worked side by side to ensure that every veteran felt seen, supported, and valued. These efforts reflect Atlantic City’s broader mission to create a community where all individuals—especially those who have sacrificed for others—are treated with respect and care.

The South Jersey Regional Stand Down was not a one-day gesture, but part of a deeper, continuing commitment to Atlantic City’s veterans. It was a clear demonstration that when local government, service providers, and volunteers come together, lives can be changed.

As the day came to a close, the sense of connection and community lingered. The City of Atlantic City walked away not only having offered services, but having made a powerful statement: our veterans matter, and we will continue to stand with them.
